forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
Let's tackle one problem at the time, OK?  

**1)** there is NO problem whatsoever in***dual*** booting Windows 98 and XP (of course if you call it ***duel*** booting you create an unfriendly climate in the PC that may be the cause of the problem ![:thumbsup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbsup.gif))  
**2)** The fact that USB flash sticks are "solid state" means that the y are "solid state" NOT that they are "solid".  
Any flash based devices has practically unlimited reading cycles but a determined number of write cycles.  
There is NO reliable and updated literature on the topic, the general idea is 100.000 write cycles, but this was (if ever) true for early generation of Flash based memory, the actual figure now is probably higher.  
**BUT** , you miss the fact that some filesystems (NTFS or any semi-journaled or journaled filesystem) and some particular OS files (typically pagefile) are accessed and written to hundred of times, without you knowing it.  
As I see it running a system on a USB Flash device as an everyday OS on a NTFS partition without implementing particular workarounds and "tricks" means frying the device in a short number of days, maybe weeks.  
Besides, you have to take into account that an average USB stick has a throughput between 12 and 20 Mb/s, averaging at the best 15 Mb/s, which is roughly 1/10th of a "normal" internal ATA 133 disk or sata I one, your system will be SLOW.  
If you use FAT16 or FAT32 it is likely that the stick will last years.  
Don't even think of putting a pagefile on the stick, and DEFINITELY NOT a growing one.  
Modern USB stick controllers use internal wear leveling algorithms that contribute to extend the expected life of a device very, very considerably.  
As often happens in htis sad world, you usually get what you pay for, a top-speed-with-wear-leveling USB stick will behave MUCH better both in speed and duration, that a no-name cheap stick.  
Read a bit around (not necessarily "USB stick" relatred, more generally about flash based storeage devices:  
[http://en.wikipedia....ki/Flash_memory](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flash_memory "External link")  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=8757](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=8757 "External link")  
[http://www.boot-land...?...ic=9615\&hl=](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=9615&hl= "External link")  
[http://www.storagese...-endurance.html](http://www.storagesearch.com/ssdmyths-endurance.html "External link")  
[http://www.esacademy...sh/lifetime.htm](http://www.esacademy.com/faq/docs/flash/lifetime.htm "External link")  
[http://en.wikipedia..../Wear_levelling](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wear_levelling "External link")  
[http://www.corsair.c...ar_leveling.pdf](http://www.corsair.com/_faq/FAQ_flash_drive_wear_leveling.pdf "External link")  
[http://www.flashmemo...1_F2B_Roman.pdf](http://www.flashmemorysummit.com/English/Collaterals/Proceedings/2009/20090811_F2B_Roman.pdf "External link")  

**3)** There are workarounds for booting on motherboards that ONLY accept FD devices:  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=9460](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=9460 "External link")  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=7932](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=7932 "External link")  
though be warned that while most motherboards will accept any size of the unpartitioned FD devices, many will have a 512 Mb limit and a few actually expect a 1,44 Mb floppy size.  
Your Mileage May VARY.  

**4)** You will need some more effort than "right clicking a drive icon", but you will also need to study a bit the matter.  
Here is some initial reading:  
[http://www.ranish.com/part/primer.htm](http://www.ranish.com/part/primer.htm "External link")  
[http://www.pcguide.c...f/hdd/index.htm](http://www.pcguide.com/ref/hdd/index.htm "External link")  

![:whistling:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/happy22.gif)  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> Do disk hard drives have a limited number of writes too? NO, they are of course subject to wear but they have not the same kind of "limited number of write cycles". They are NOT "eternal", but they DO NOT wera because of writes, they usually wear "mechanically". > My friend also mentioned a upcoming hard drive that was entirely solid state. Would that drive use new technology that would allow a limited number of writes? Or just that they would increase its durability so that it would just have a hell of alot? > > I figured a additional bonus to running my OS off my flash drive would be the nearly nonexistent access time. But it might be slower in other ways, how might I compare speeds, got a program link for that? If you had taken your time to read the links you actually asked for, such solid state hard drives are on the market and in use since a fair bit of time. You completely fail to understand that between the actual device and the actual motherboard there is a connection through a DATA BUS, that in the case of USB drives is a (very, very tight) bottleneck, while on internal high speed bus, like SATA, it is not. SSD's are meant as replacement for INTERNAL hard disk drives. ANY "high-speed" device connected to a "low-speed" bus (such as USB) will obviously give you "low-speed".
> Could I possible assign all temporary drive usage including swap drive/"virtual ram" to the actual hard drive and just run the OS off the flash drive so that writing to the flash drive is limited to updates and such? The three OS I want to use are win98, XP, and linux (still trying to decide which one, maybe ubuntu? Anyone recommend a particular linux?) I would try solving your current problem before introducing another OS in the setup, there are high probabiliites to worsen the whatever problem you are currently experiencing. > A friend says that win98 can be emulated on XP, so maybe I dont have to worry about running it straight? But what program compatability and system requirements are there? Wouldn't it be more demanding to run win98 in emulation on XP then directly? Sure it is. As a rule of thumb, a "real" emulation (a Virtual Machine) is MUCH slower that "direct", with a factor of 3 to 1 against or 2,5 to 1 against. You can usually run Win9x apps under WINE (under Linux), but games are usually very, very difficult to setup as they mostly use undocumented or direct accesses to the underlying hardware. DOSBOX: [http://www.dosbox.com/](http://www.dosbox.com/ "External link") is a good platform for DOS games: [http://www.dosbox.com/comp_list.php](http://www.dosbox.com/comp_list.php "External link")? jaclaz

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> That erase program you link me to is for secure deletion of hard drive information, not flash drive deletion so that you don't have to worry about slow down for write actions as soon. Know of a program for that? It is the SAME thing: you right 00's to the whole device. The device won't know (or care) for the reason WHY you write 00's to it: * just the fun of it * privacy/security * "worry about slow down for write actions as soon"
You can use a hex/disk editor, a command line app (but I seem to understand you are not very familiar with them) or a GUI program, I pointed you to just one of them. Here is another nice one: [http://www.roadkil.n...hp?ProgramID=14](http://www.roadkil.net/program.php?ProgramID=14 "External link") You won't find a program that states "flash drive deletion so that you don't have to worry about slow down for write actions as soon" simply because it is, as SAID, perfectly **UN** needed, and it WON'T change ANYTHING in the "slow down for write actions as soon" any better than a simple format. Until you don't get convinced of the above, I don't think we will get very further. ![:thumbup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbup.gif) The filesystem could not care less if a drive contains 00's, 42's or 17's (the latter however usually means an unlucky device ![:thumbup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbup.gif)). If the filesystem indexing structures are empty (the actual FAT tables or NTFS MFT's) the drive is to ALL practical effect, empty. This is achieved by simply FORMATTING the drive. WIPING is in most cases completely UNneeded and only a source for pointless additional stress to the device. ![:rolleyes:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/rolleyes.gif) jaclaz

forumNotes.author: paraglider
forumNotes.content:
Yes ssd drives also have limited number of writes to each cell. It depends on the type of ssd. If based on MLC technology ( most are ) then each cell has a life of 10000 writes per cell. If its a SLC SSD then each cell has a life of around 100000 writes ( these are much more expensive).  

The firmware in the SSD will employ extremely sophisticated levelling algorithms to ensure that even if you write 10000 times to what the OS thinks is the same address that the write uses different cells in the SSD.  

Manufacturers claim 5 year lifes for MLC ssd's in real world use. Nobody really knows yet how long they last if you use one for your NTFS boot drive and page file.
